captions.text:
You've probably learned that leaves are green
because they're full of a green molecule called

chlorophyll - it's the reason for the greenness
of plants, from moss-green moss to grass-green

grass to ever-green evergreens. And the reason
chlorophyll is so incredibly popular--showing

up in nearly every plant on Earth--is that
it's good at soaking up sunlight. The more

light a plant gets, the more energy it has
to make sugar and grow tulips and kumquats
and do all the other things plants do.

But wait a second: doesn't the fact that chlorophyll
is green mean that it's actually bad at absorbing

green light? I mean, sunlight is composed
of the whole rainbow of colors, each a separate

wavelength, and the colors we see when we
look at a leaf are the wavelengths that leaf

isn't absorbing -- that is, the ones that
bounce off the leaf and reach our eyes.

Chlorophyll is great at absorbing reds and
blues, but if it were really awesome, wouldn't

it absorb all colors of light, green included,
giving us a world full of black moss and black
grass and everblack trees?

So why aren't leaves black? And since they
apparently don't have to be black, what's

stopping them from being red or blue instead?
Is green just Nature's favorite color, or

is there something special about those wavelengths
of light?

The short answer is that we don't know for
sure.

Some scientists speculate it's serendipity
that plants today are green. Long ago, Earth's

oceans were filled with purple single-celled
organisms called archaea. Being purple, they

absorbed green light and let red and blue
pass through. The theory is that this "minus-green"

light was the only source of solar energy
in the deep water below, so bacteria living

there got really good at absorbing everything
else but green. And the molecule that did
the light-absorbing? Chlorophyll! Maybe.

In the long run, what we do know is that Chlorophyll,
as wasteful as its failure to absorb green

light may be, turned out to have other biochemical
advantages over the purple competition. And

perhaps as a result of this ancient biological
rivalry, the plant world today is green, and
not purple or red or blue.

Of course, you might still wonder why plants
didn't develop black leaves once they emerged

from the depths. I mean, they changed a lot
of other things going from bacteria to mighty

redwood! Well, maybe it's simply that nature
isn't about perfection, and life doesn't need

"flawless" black to get by - just "good enough"
green. Or maybe plants were even more clever

and turned the weakness of chlorophyll into
a strength? But we'll have to leave that story
for later...

comments.text:
I have a simple explanation.
Chlorophyll is effective at making sugars from the energy of the light and 
other atoms. Because it is effective it doesn't need to change. Chlorophyll 
is also made out of atoms. That bunch of atoms reflects a green colour. It 
needs to made up of other atoms to make the colour black or so. The 
combination of atoms that cause the black colour might not be able to be as 
effective as the combination of atoms that cause the green colour.
Maybe the temperatures get even too high when it is black which could 
reduce the efficiency and it may cause water to evaporate too fast.
I think it has a green colour by accident. Other colours need other atoms 
and it might not be as efficient as green. I am not a scientist though. So 
don't use these arguments as facts.﻿

comments.text:
We do know! how can he speak for everyone? This guys is so UNresearched! 
here are the facts about 
plants:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                
When chlorophyll works and captures sunlight, it's green. When zanaphyll 
captures sunlight, it's purple. All plants have zanaphyll in them. (their 
back up life system that supports 30% of their energy intake) The zanaphyll 
resides just underneath the chlorophyll. So to recap: all plants are 
purple--they're just covered up by green 
chlorophyll.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
Now, in some plants, through evolution and breeding and mendelian tricks, 
we've bred the chlorophyll to die, so its death naturally occurs at the end 
of a life cycle or through response to cold or any other external factors. 
But in some seeds we've bred naturally, the chlorophyll just dies at the 
end anyway. Most plants can be purpled up by getting the right DIF (short 
for differential), which is your day to night temperential temperature 
difference.
                                                                                                                  
(nomenclature are very important when dealing with scientific names) In 
truth Xanthophylls are not as quite as simple as that as really purple is 
made by a mixture of other colors such as reds, yellows and such as much as 
what we are seeing is "purple" but that is the "net" effect﻿
comments.author: WorldTruthSociety

comments.text:
+ADU Aquascaping Most of us realize life is much more complex than this, 
however that doesn't mean it's wrong. It's simplified so normal people can 
understand it, as are most scientific theories including gravity, the big 
bang, the basic laws, the 4 forces and so on. They do explain why leaves 
turn different colors in another video but the concept is the same: colors 
are produced based on the chemical makeup, which are the same reasons 
supernovae are so colorful, and why we have different colored paints. We 
may not be specialists, however this video does its best to explain it to 
people. You, however, sound like the idiot. If you're so smart, and know 
the inner workings are beyond a normal persons comprehension, then your own 
intelligence should be signalling you "hey, there's no reason to assume the 
average joe will know what this is". Simplification, and being wrong, are 
two entirely different things.﻿

comments.text:
+ufewl  Keep in mind chemical makeup (light absorption and heat retention) 
dictate both how hot something "feels" and how quickly it can cool down. 
Asphalt can feel much hotter than grass at the same temperature, simply 
because it can transfer the heat more quickly elsewhere. But it's also 
ridiculously good at absorbing light energy, being dense, dark and I 
imagine it's silica based (I've never really cared to look into it's 
chemical compounds).
comments.author: Calvin DiBartolo

comments.text:
+Arthur Clini Souza 
Petrol engines are only about 30% efficient, the other 70% is lost as heat.
Sugar cane (the best plant) is only about 8% efficient in converting 
sunlight to biomass, but not all the other 92% end up as heat in the plant 
about 1/2 is reflected away.
I am not sure how much heat is generated but it is a significant amount.
Black would be worse for photosynthesis and black absorbs all colours, if 
you ever feet a black tarmac on a sunny day it will be very warm.

Deserts have no water and water evaporating produces a cooling effect 
(which is why we sweat), water also evaporates off/from plants which is why 
they wilt to conserve water. Plants reflect a of light, but deserts will 
too unless they are black, plants reflect a bit more than deserts but not 
lot more, depends on the colour.

For example in the same sun
Grass (green) is 13C
Concrete (light grey)15C
Asphalt  (dark grey/black)  19C

http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Features/HottestSpot/page2.php

comments.author: gamwizrd1

comments.text:
Good guess! But the concept of "opposite colors" only exists in art class. 
Light is like a wave, and we see different lengths of waves as different 
colors. All colors of light hit the leaves, but molecules in a leaf are 
only good at absorbing longer wavelengths (red) and shorter wavelengths 
(blue). The green just bounces off and hits your eye! X-Rays are REALLY 
short waves of light, and radio and phone signals are REALLY long waves. If 
we had different eyes we could see them too :P
comments.author: gamwizrd1

comments.text:
Without any competition for the light, evolution favored absorbing the 
wavelength with the greatest intensity; green.
